figures.interpretation_text:
What this means

The chart shows J .E. and L .E. Mabee Foundation as the top funder, awarding $8,000,000 in total; as a Foundation, it aligns with preferred funder types and may be a high-capacity prospect for a $100,000–$500,000 request supporting Youth education and after-school STEM, including equipment needs in TX/US. year_issued field unavailable.
figures.label: Top Funders

highlights: J .E. and L .E. Mabee Foundation leads in total awarded amount
summary.label: Top Funders

figures.interpretation_text:
What this means

The amount distribution is right-skewed: across 19 records the median is $55,293 while the 90th percentile is $2,000,000, indicating typical awards are smaller than your $100k–$500k 2‑year budget, with a few large outliers. For a Youth education and after-school STEM effort in TX/US, plan for a mix of smaller foundation/corporate requests or phased co-funding aligned to equipment needs and limited staff capacity. year_issued field unavailable.
figures.label: Amount Distribution

figures.interpretation_text:
What this means
Based on a single 2023 data point, the total awarded amount remained flat at $9,483,148; additional years are unavailable, so broader trends can’t be assessed. For your Youth education and after-school STEM initiative in TX/US (two-year, $100k–$500k), align requests to Foundation/Corporate funders and prioritize equipment needs while accounting for limited staff capacity.

narrative_outline: Funding Landscape: Top Funders and Concentration
Geographic Footprint: Locations and Relative Presence
Temporal Dynamics: Year-over-Year Funding and Volume
Grant Size Profile: Distribution, Outliers, and Drivers

funder_candidates.name: Thdf II Inc DBA the Home Depot Foundation & Homer Fund
funder_candidates.rationale: In 2023 they funded $351,000 in Austin for community and economic development serving low-income people (Meals on Wheels and More Inc). This fits city projects that improve community infrastructure or services for low-income residents. Good match for municipal initiatives tied to community improvement. Contact difficulty: Not available in this dataset.

funder_candidates.name: United Way of Greater Houston
funder_candidates.rationale: Gave $134,416 to an Austin education program for children and youth (Girls Empowerment Network). Strong signal they support youth education in Austin. Good for after-school, mentoring, and student success proposals. Contact difficulty: Not available in this dataset.

funder_candidates.name: Quincy and Estine Lee Char Fnd Fb992
funder_candidates.rationale: Multiple $50,000 awards supporting ESL, early childhood education, education services, and youth development in Austin. Good fit for small-to-mid education and after-school programs. They have funded general support too. Contact difficulty: Not available in this dataset.

funder_candidates.name: Meadows Foundation Inc
funder_candidates.rationale: Provided $110,000 for community and economic development to a local Austin nonprofit (Guadalupe Neighborhood Development Corporation). Good for neighborhood-serving, low-income resident-focused projects, including community education spaces. Contact difficulty: Not available in this dataset.

funder_candidates.name: The Moody Foundation
funder_candidates.rationale: Funded two grants totaling $406,560 to Central Texas Community Health Centers for graduate/professional education with a youth and at-risk youth focus. Consider if your project links youth to workforce or health-career pathways. Contact difficulty: Not available in this dataset.

funder_candidates.name: Nolan Ryan Foundation
funder_candidates.rationale: Gave $60,000 for youth development. Could fit youth sports, mentorship, or character-building programs run by the city or in partnership with schools. Contact difficulty: Not available in this dataset.

funder_candidates.name: Ross Baldwin Elementary PTA
funder_candidates.rationale: Four grants of about $55,293 each supported education services and elementary/secondary education at Galindo Elementary in Austin. If your city program partners with local schools (e.g., after-school), this is a nearby, realistic small-grant route. Contact difficulty: Not available in this dataset.

funder_candidates.name: J .E. and L .E. Mabee Foundation
funder_candidates.rationale: Very large dollars in Austin ($8,000,000 total), but all to Dell Children’s Medical Center Foundation ($2,000,000 per grant) for children’s/specialty hospital care. Consider only if your city project is a partnership with children’s health/hospital programs. Contact difficulty: Not available in this dataset.

response_tuning.text: Set your first ask near the local median award (~$55,293). This is a realistic starting point for new relationships.

For large, collaborative projects with health partners, note that Austin saw grants up to $2,000,000 each (hospital-related). Only pursue big asks at that scale if you have a hospital or major institutional partner.
Emphasize youth impact. Children and youth were the most common population served and received the largest total dollars in Austin.
Mirror common subject terms in your narrative (e.g., “Education services,” “Youth development,” “Community and economic development”) so reviewers see immediate alignment.
Anchor your need statement in local impact. All grants in this dataset were for Austin—show neighborhood-level outcomes and citywide benefits.
Tailor each proposal to the funder’s pattern. For example, position Home Depot Foundation requests as community and economic development serving low-income residents.
Design a clear program plan with outputs and outcomes. Many listed awards were for program support; include a simple logic model, milestones, and measures.
Use small, quick wins to build momentum. Recent local grants clustered around $50,000–$60,000 (e.g., $50,000 and ~$55,293 awards).
If you serve low-income residents, make that explicit. Austin grants directed $461,000 to community/economic development for low-income people.
Avoid poor fits. Do not pitch purely education-only projects to hospital-focused funders like Mabee unless you have a concrete children’s health partnership.
Consider both program and general support asks. Program support is common, but some funders here also made general support awards.
Confirm deadlines and cycles on funder websites. This dataset shows awards in 2023 but does not include application timing or success rates.
Cite credible local partners with a track record (e.g., organizations in Austin that recently received grants) to strengthen your readiness and capacity story.

sections.markdown_body: Seeking support for a youth education and after-school STEM program serving low-income youth and students, piloting expansion in the Austin, TX metro and operating in TX and across the U.S. in partnership with local schools and libraries. Over a 2-year period with a $100,000–$500,000 budget, the intent is to expand access to technology/equipment to boost STEM enrollment by 25% and improve participating students’ standardized test scores by 10%.
sections.title: Intake Summary

sections.markdown_body:
Problem: You need a quick map of where the money is.

- In 2023, $9,483,148 went to 19 grants. 100% of grants in our data were issued in 2023 (DP-CDF3E8EE, DP-D413C41F).
- One funder gave $8,000,000, which is about 84% of all dollars (DP-D6896CE7).
- Typical grant sizes: 25% were $50,000 or less; the median was $55,293; 75% were $277,140 or less; the smallest was $30,000; the largest was $2,000,000. There were four $2,000,000 grants (DP-F46538A7, DP-F4FB9133).

What This Means for You: Most awards are around $50,000–$60,000, with a few very large ones. If you are new to a funder, plan your first ask near the median ($55,293).
sections.title: Your Funding Landscape

sections.markdown_body:
Problem: It’s hard to know who to call first.

Based on our analysis (DP-D6896CE7, DP-E1587099):
- Large private foundations: J. E. and L. E. Mabee Foundation — $8,000,000 for children’s and specialty hospital care.
- Corporate foundation: Home Depot Foundation — $351,000 for community and economic development.
- Regional/statewide foundations: Moody Foundation — $406,560 for graduate/professional education; Meadows Foundation — $110,000 for community and economic development.
- Community funder: United Way — $134,416 for education.
- School-affiliated group: A PTA gave $221,172 for education services and elementary/secondary education.
- Family/named foundations: Quincy and Estine Lee Charitable Fund — $200,000 across ESL, early childhood, education services, youth development; Nolan Ryan Foundation — $60,000 for youth development.

What This Means for You: Match your project to the funder’s pattern. For facility or neighborhood upgrades, call the corporate or community/economic development funders. For school-based programs, contact school-affiliated groups or education-focused foundations.
sections.title: Types of Funders to Contact

sections.markdown_body:
Problem: You need a realistic number that gets approved.

Based on our analysis (DP-F46538A7, DP-F4FB9133):
- Median grant was $55,293; 25% were $50,000 or less.
- 25% were $277,140 or more; the max was $2,000,000 (four such grants).

What This Means for You: Start with $50,000–$60,000 for a first ask or a pilot. If your project is larger (multi-site or multi-year), aim for $100,000–$300,000. Only pursue $2,000,000-level asks if your work resembles hospital-scale child health projects in the data.
sections.title: How Much Money to Ask For

sections.markdown_body:
Problem: You want to apply when funders are most active.

Based on our analysis (DP-D413C41F, DP-CDF3E8EE):
- All grants in our dataset were issued in 2023. We do not have month-by-month timing or trends for other years.

What This Means for You: Use funder deadlines, not seasons. Visit the listed funders’ sites (e.g., Mabee, Moody, Home Depot Foundation, United Way, Meadows) to note their next deadlines (DP-D6896CE7, DP-E1587099). Set your internal due dates a few weeks earlier so you can get approvals on time.
sections.title: Best Times to Apply

sections.markdown_body:
Problem: You need to show the right focus.

Based on our analysis:
- By amount, about 84% of dollars went to children’s and specialty hospital care ($8,000,000 of $9,483,148; DP-6A5CDB11).
- Community and economic development received $461,000 (~5%); graduate/professional education received $406,560 (~4%); education categories together received about $1,022,148 (~11%) (DP-6A5CDB11).
- By count, 58% of grants served children and youth (11 of 19). Students were 21%; low-income people 11%; at-risk youth 11% (DP-2C54CD18).
- Larger funders and subjects that already attract more funding tend to produce larger grants (DP-0D05A710).

What This Means for You: If your project helps children or youth, say it clearly and early. If not, consider a youth component (for example, teen programs at a community center) to fit common priorities. For community upgrades, use the community/economic development angle shown in the data.
sections.title: What Funders Want to See

sections.markdown_body:
Opportunity: Your location can boost your chances.

Based on our analysis (DP-A4DB3CA1, DP-6A5CDB11):
- 100% of grants were in Austin (19 of 19).
- Total funding for Austin was $9,483,148. The largest amounts were in children’s and specialty hospital care ($4,000,000 each).

What This Means for You: If your project serves Austin residents, say so in the first paragraph. Name the city, the neighborhoods you serve, and the local partners. This matches where funders have already given.
sections.title: Your Geographic Advantages

sections.markdown_body:
Problem: You need a simple, strong story.

Use the data to frame your project (DP-2C54CD18, DP-6A5CDB11, DP-F46538A7, DP-E1587099):
- Lead with who benefits, especially children and youth (58% of grants by count).
- Link your work to funded subjects, like community/economic development or education.
- State your ask in a common range: “We request $55,000 to launch…” (near the median $55,293).
- Tie your impact to Austin to match 100% of awards in the data.

What This Means for You: Write a 3–4 sentence opener: Who you serve (children/youth if true), what you will do, where in Austin, and how much you need ($50,000–$60,000 to start). Then add one sentence connecting to a funder’s past giving area (for example, community development or education).
sections.title: Positioning Your Project

sections.markdown_body:
Opportunity: A clear plan speeds up funding.

Days 1–30 — Map your options using the data:
1. Pick your main subject (e.g., community/economic development, education) and population (children/youth, students) to match common awards (DP-B8A080BA, DP-2C54CD18).
2. List 8–10 likely funders from our data and amounts: Mabee ($8,000,000), Moody ($406,560), Home Depot Foundation ($351,000), PTA ($221,172), Quincy and Estine Lee ($200,000), United Way ($134,416), Meadows ($110,000), Nolan Ryan ($60,000) (DP-D6896CE7, DP-E1587099).
3. Choose 3–5 targets that fit your project type.

Days 31–60 — Build strong, right-sized asks:
1. Draft a 2-page concept with a clear Austin focus (all grants in Austin; DP-A4DB3CA1).
2. Set your ask near the median for first-time requests ($50,000–$60,000). Reserve larger asks ($100,000–$300,000) for projects with bigger scope (DP-F46538A7).
3. If you serve children/youth, highlight that on page 1 (58% of grants by count; DP-2C54CD18).

Days 61–90 — Submit and follow up:
1. Check each target’s deadline and submit complete applications (DP-D6896CE7, DP-E1587099).
2. Track submissions and plan brief follow-ups after deadlines.
3. Prepare simple results you will track (for example, number of youth served) to match common focus areas.

What This Means for You: Aim for 3–5 quality submissions in 90 days. Use the median ask first, align to children/youth when true, and stress that your work serves Austin.
sections.title: Your 90-Day Action Plan
